## Conversation that answers the provided questions:
**AI Assistant:**
Hey there! I'm here to assist you in understanding Verus. What's on your mind today?

**User:**
I've been playing around with Verus, and I'm trying to understand some of the options. What is the purpose of the `-blockversion=<n>` option in Verus?

**AI Assistant:**
The `-blockversion=<n>` option is used to override the block version to test forking scenarios. The default block version is 4. This option allows you to simulate different block versions for testing purposes.

**User:**
That makes sense. I was also wondering about the work queue for RPC calls. What is the default depth of the work queue to service RPC calls in Verus?

**AI Assistant:**
The default depth of the work queue to service RPC calls in Verus is 16. This can be overridden using the `-rpcworkqueue=<n>` option. This setting determines how many RPC calls can be queued up before they start getting rejected.
What is the purpose of the `-blockversion=<n>` option in Verus?
The `-blockversion=<n>` option is used to override the block version to test forking scenarios. The default block version is 4.

`-blockversion=<n>`    Override block version to test forking scenarios (default: 4) ## RPC options: `-rpcworkqueue=<n>`    Set the depth of the work queue to service RPC calls (default: 16) `-rpcservertimeout=<n>`    Timeout during HTTP requests (default: 30) compiled by Oink.vrsc@.
